name: Suslin tree
rephrased: A special type of infinite tree where every chain and antichain is countable.
implication_form: If ZFC is consistent, then the existence of a Suslin tree is independent of ZFC.
explained: A Suslin tree is a mathematical structure defined within set theory as a tree of height ω1 (the first uncountable ordinal) that satisfies two key properties: every chain (branch) is countable, and every antichain is countable. It is a specific type of Aronszajn tree, which is an uncountable tree with no uncountable chains or antichains, but unlike the general Aronszajn tree, the Suslin tree does not have a certain 'witnessing' property related to dense sets in the definition of a Suslin algebra.
terms: Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice (ZFC)
